channel.title: Which Distro?
channel.description:
Soo...
I was thinking Linux Mint, but should I do Xubuntu? Or Arch? Or another one? I've only tried Linux Mint and Ubuntu so far. I'm a noob aswell so please take that into consideration. Thanks!

item.title: Which Distro?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Xx R A G 3 R, post:7, topic:352345”]I ended up going with Ubuntu, once I get more use to it I think I might switch it up to something else.

dsl

en.wikipedia.org

Damn Small Linux

Damn Small Linux (commonly abbreviated DSL) is a computer operating system for the x86 family of personal computers. It is free and open source software under the terms of the GNU GPL and other free and open source licenses. It was designed to run graphical applications on older PC hardware—for example, machines with 486/early Pentium processors and very little memory. DSL is a Live CD with a size of 50 MB. What originally started as an experiment to see how much software could fit in 50 MB event...


??[/quote]soz i meant to say lfs

Read full topic

item.title: Which Distro?
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

Gnome is the desktop environment, basically everything you can see is Gnome. But Gnome is really bloated and ‘slow’ compared to other desktop environments. I wouldn’t say they’re better, but they’re good alternatives. Xubuntu isn’t as heavy on system resources, and kubuntu adds a more windows like user interface.

Read full topic

item.title: Which Distro?
item.dc:creator: @Xx_R_A_G_3_R Xx R A G 3 R
item.description:
@Xx_R_A_G_3_R wrote:

I ended up installing ubuntu as a dual boot on my computer, and i have to say i really like it. i’m just looking for a well-rounded desktop enviroment right now. i’m still getting use to ubuntu but it’s really noob friendly, i have a question though. it seems everyone hates ubuntu 'cause of gnome. what is gnome? also, why is xubuntu and kubuntu better then ubuntu?

This question prolly makes me look stupid, but i want to know.

Read full topic

item.title: Which Distro?
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

Go with xubuntu if you’re worried about system resource, any other *buntu will be good for a beginner though. How much time have you spent with ubuntu? You might want to get used to using it before you start hopping around to different distributions. Make sure you get a good feel for the OS, and get past the learning curve.

I wouldn’t suggest using Arch unless you’re familiar with Command Line, you’ll spend quite a bit of time in it before you’ll even see a desktop environment.

Read full topic

item.title: Which Distro?
item.dc:creator: @Dzo -Dzo-
item.description:
@Dzo wrote:

Well what are you looking for? I’m assuming a well-rounded desktop distribution.

Or, perhaps its just the desktop environment that you want to sample (The part you can see - eg. Xfce, Gnome, Kde). If so, ubuntu is a great distribution to do so. With very easy commands like “sudo apt-get install kubuntu-desktop” and such. The pain is removing the de’s that you don’t like…

Anywho, if you really are out to try some new distros, Arch would be a great place to start. Slackware is also good to learn a little. And gentoo if your patient.


-Dzo

Read full topic
